paragraph.paragraph:
A break point is a point used to halt execution of a Project for
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel debuggingDebugging purposes. For example, the code that you wish to examine requires some fairly complex steps in order for it to be executed. It is not possible to step through the whole Projects execution line by line, so you set a Break Point. When the Break Point is reached, execution will stop, and you will be able to debug the project.
You have as many break points as you wish in a project.

You may also turn a regular Break Point into a
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel Conditional Break PointConditional Break Point by modifying its properties. For more information regarding this, click
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel Conditional Break Pointhere .
paragraph.heading: 2Setting a Break Point
paragraph.paragraph: There are two ways to set a Break Point:

list.item: Select New Breakpoint from the Debug Menu which opens up a dialog allowing you to specify a new Break Point.

Left click on the left hand margin of the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel EditorEditor , corresponding to the line of source code where you wish to place the Break Point.

The screenshot above shows sample source code in the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel EditorEditor , for which a Break Point has been set.
paragraph.heading: 2Running To A Break Point
paragraph.paragraph: Execute the Project using Start From the Debug menu. The Project will then execute until a Break point is reached:

The screenshot above demonstrates the appearance of the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel EditorEditor when a break point has been reached, and the execution has stopped. The line that is highlighted in yellow is the next line of the project's code that will be executed.
paragraph.heading: 2Stepping Through the Project
paragraph.paragraph:
To follow the execution of the system during
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel debuggingDebugging , you need to step through the code, line by line. This allows you to see exactly what is happening within the system.

There are two ways of stepping during
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel debuggingDebugging :

list.item:
Step Into - If the current line to be executed contains one or more
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel routineroutines that may be executed, then the execution will step into the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel routineroutine to execute it one line at a time. If there is no such
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel routineroutine , then the current line for execution will be incremented.

Step Over - Even if the current line to be executed contains one or more
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel routineroutine , then the execution of their bodies will not be traced, and the current line for execution will be incremented.

image.alt_text: Editor Window With BreakPoint Stepped Over

paragraph.paragraph:
The screenshot above demonstrates a single stepping from the breakpoint to the next line of code to be executed. As the line of code with the Break Point did not contain a
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel routineroutine , then Step Into and Step Over had the same effect.

Once you are
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel debuggingDebugging , you may also run to a particular point in the source code, without setting a Break Point, by right clicking on the line in the
0 !DefaultAssociativeIndex Eiffel EditorEditor that you wish to run to, and select Run To Cursor from the context menu.
